answers.answer: Since labs results and reference ranges vary from lab to lab, we need to look at the reference ranges that go with that  T3 and T4 data.

It can be challenging finding a good endocrinologist and some will specialize in various conditions, such as diabetes or hypoparathyroidism.   You may have to go to several before you find one that 1) you like and 2) has experience in treating your particular condition.   We went through 4 doctors before finding someone that met our criteria.   Always ask lots of questions.   During our first visit, we conducted a mini-interview of the doctor, asking various questions about their experience in this area, years in practice, treating other patients with the same or similar conditions, authoring articles, whether getting a 2nd opinion is recommended, can you refer me to someone that does have experience in this area, what are the alternatives, etc.  One of the big questions we always asked was:  if it was your spouse, son, daughter or loved one had this problem, where would you send them for treatment?  Also, check with the National Institute of Health, the Mayo Clinic and John Hopkins.

question: Hi,I am new to this, I have family history of Thyroid issues, my sister has thyroid cancer, they found this summer a multinodular goiter, I have been on Levothyroxine since. I have had signs for awhile but just putting the puzzle together, after reading about Hypothroid, my body temp has always been low average 96 to 97, weight gain for over a yr. I get Bronchities at least twice a yr, shortness of breath, My family phy. has been treating me, but I am going to look into a specialist esp. because of my sister. My last test results were, t-3 1.160 / t-4 1.630 and tsh 0.007 How do I find the right doctor who can take care of me but my concerns with family history, I am always tired, at the moment.Thanks for advice, God Bless.
title: How to find the right Doctor.
